text: Trinidad and Tobago is expected to compete at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo. Originally scheduled to take place from 24 July to 9 August 2020, the Games have been postponed to 23 July to 8 August 2021, due to the COVID-19 pandemic. It will be the nation's eighteenth appearance at the Summer Olympics, although it previously competed in four other editions as a British colony, and as part of the West Indies Federation. ==Athletics== Athletes from Trinidad and Tobago further achieved the entry standards, either by qualifying time or by world ranking, in the following track and field events (up to a maximum of 3 |-align=center |align=left|Keshorn Walcott |align=left|Men's javelin throw | | | | |-align=center |align=left|Andwuelle Wright |align=left|Men's long jump | | | | |} ==Cycling== ===Road=== For the first time in history, Trinidad and Tobago entered one rider to compete in the women's Olympic road race, by virtue of her top 100 individual finish (for women) in the UCI World Ranking. {|class=wikitable style=font-size:90%;text-align:center |- !Athlete !Event !Time !Rank |- |align=left| |align=left|Women's road race | | |} ===Track=== Following the completion of the 2020 UCI Track
